title: Using cellphone mobility data to make sense of infection heterogeneity

markdown.headingText: Using cellphone mobility data to make sense of infection heterogeneity
markdown.markdown:
EPID 684 Spatial Epidemiology 4/14/2022

Jon Zelner `jzelner@umich.edu` [`epibayes.io`](https://epibayes.io)

![](../images/epid_logo.png){.absolute bottom=0 right=50 width="440" height="100"} ## Agenda - What are the uses and challenges provided by üì± mobility data ? - How can mobility data tell us about patterns of social segregation and inequality? - Smoothing in 2D ## Mobility data have become more prominent during the COVID-19 pandemic {.imgslide} ![Relating mobility to COVID-19 spread in the early days of the pandemic [@glanz2020]](../images/cellphone_mobility_covid.png) ## What can mobility data capture that is relevant to understanding infectious disease transmission? :::{.fragment} ![](../images/grantz_data_collected.png) ::: ## Mobility data have revealed potential drivers of inequities in COVID-19 risk ![Changes in mobility by income decile in early 2020 in the U.S. from Chang et al. [@chang2020]](../images/chang_mobility_change.png) ## Income-related mobility differences reflect differential occupational exposures ![Estimated infections acquired in different types of locations by income decile from [@chang2020]](../images/chang_location_infection.png) ## Have become important inputs to theoretical models ![Mobility data were used to simulate SARS-CoV-2 transmission under different housing policy scenarios in [@nande2021]](../images/nande_evictions_covid_transmission.png) ## Cell phone data come in different shapes and sizes ![Relationships between population covered and cellphone data type [@grantz2020]](../images/grantz_mobile_phone_levels.png) ## A lot of processing and analysis choices take place between data collection and use ![Using cellphone data to craft mobility networks in Italy during COVID-19 [@pepe2020]](../images/mobility_data_processing.png) ## What might be worrisome about the rise of mobility data in epidemiology? - Privacy üïµÔ∏è - May drive technocratic vs. principled approaches to policy and decision-making - Focus in on micro factors with sufficient attention to the macro drivers of micro behavior. - Data may not be representative of variation in intensity and nature of contact. - Simulation models built off of these data may appear more authoritative but have no more predictive usefulness than less-complex models. # Mobility Neighborhood Disadvantage and COVID-19 ü¶† risk ## What is the distinction between residential and mobility neighborhood disadvantage? ![How do Levy at all conceptualize the meaning of MND and RND for risk? [@levy2022]](../images/levy_rnd_vs_mnd.png) ## What is triple neighborhood disadvantage(TND)? - Extends the concept of neighborhood disadvantage to include connected locations. - This includes neighborhood of residence, neighborhoods visited by people in a given location, and neighborhoods sending visitors to the neighborhood of interest. - MND has been shown to be associated with increased violence risk after adjusting for RND [@levy2020; @sampson2020]. ## MND predicts increased COVID-19 cases after adjustment for RND ![](../images/levy_nd_risks.png) ## MND & RND are strong - but variable - mediators of associations with race/ethnicty ![Mediation of neighborhood percent Black residents by RND, MND](../images/levy_rnd_mnd_mediation.png) ## These effects vary across groups ![Mediation of neighborhood percent Hispanic residents by RND, MND](../images/levy_rnd_mnd_mediation_hispanic.png) # Smoothing in 2 Dimensions üó∫Ô∏è ## Final hands-on!
